string-array.name: descriptions
string-array.item: On April 27, 2009, the Android 1.5 update was released, based on Linux kernel 2.6.27.[32][33] This was the first release to officially use a codename based on a dessert item ("Cupcake"), a theme which would be used for all releases henceforth. The update included several new features and UI amendments:[34]
On September 15, 2009, the Android 1.6 SDK – dubbed Donut – was released, based on Linux kernel 2.6.29.[36][37][38] Included in the update were numerous new features:[36]
On October 26, 2009, the Android 2.0 SDK – codenamed Éclair – was released, based on Linux kernel 2.6.29.[39] Changes included:[40]
On May 20, 2010, the SDK for Android 2.2 (Froyo, short for frozen yogurt) was released, based on Linux kernel 2.6.32.[44]
On December 6, 2010, the Android 2.3 (Gingerbread) SDK was released, based on Linux kernel 2.6.35

On February 22, 2011, the Android 3.0 (Honeycomb) SDK – the first tablet-only Android update – was released, based on Linux kernel 2.6.36.[67][68][69][70] The first device featuring this version, the Motorola Xoom tablet, was released on February 24, 2011

Google announced Android 4.1 (Jelly Bean) at the Google I/O conference on June 27, 2012. Based on Linux kernel 3.0.31, Jelly Bean was an incremental update with the primary aim of improving the functionality and performance of the user interface. The performance improvement involved Project Butter, which uses touch anticipation, triple buffering, extended vsync timing and a fixed frame rate of 60 fps to create a fluid and "buttery-smooth" UI.[97] Android 4.1 Jelly Bean was released to the Android Open Source Project on July 9, 2012,[98] and the Nexus 7 tablet, the first device to run Jelly Bean, was released on July 13, 2012.

Google announced Android 4.4 KitKat on September 3, 2013. Although initially under the codename, the name was changed because very few people actually know the taste of a key lime pie. Some technology bloggers also expected the Key Lime Pie release to be Android 5. KitKat debuted on Googles Nexus 5 on October 31, 2013, and was optimized to run on a greater range of devices than earlier Android versions, having 512 MB of RAM as a recommended minimum; those improvements were known as "Project Svelte" internally at Google.

Android 5.0 "Lollipop" was unveiled under the codename "Android L" on June 25, 2014, during Google I/O. It became available as official over-the-air (OTA) updates on November 12, 2014, for select devices that run distributions of Android serviced by Google, including Nexus and Google Play edition devices. Its source code was made available on November 3, 2014
Android 6.0 "Marshmallow"[1] is an upcoming update to the Android mobile operating system, most likely to be released in Q3 2015
